NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person who applies for sth., esp. a post 求职者，申请人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Graduate schools generally require applicants to submit scores on the Graduate Record Exam (GRE).

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. question to decide if sb. is right for a job 面试
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. John is being interviewed next week for the Chief Executive's job.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a business that supplies goods or services to a purchaser 供应厂商；供应者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Baosteel is the biggest supplier of steel sheets to Shanghai's auto industry.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (infml) question intensely; cook under or over direct heat 盘问；烧烤
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Tom was grilled by customs officers for several hours.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an article cut from a newspaper or magazine 剪报   clip vt. cut (a piece) from sth. larger or whole 剪下
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The old man has been collecting newspaper clippings for years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: take additional steps to further (a previous action) 采取进一步行动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. If you make a hotel booking by phone, follow it up with written confirmation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a positive feeling of wanting to push ahead with sth. 渴望；热切
in sb.'s possession 在某人手中，为某人所拥有
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His father's company has been in his hands for some years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. 亲手送交
a. likely to become or be 可能成为的；预期的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The chief function of direct-mail advertising is to familiarize prospective buyers with a product.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in my opinion 在我看来
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As I see it, this press conference is the most successful one we have ever had.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 俗话说，常言道
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As an old English saying goes, "If you want to live and thrive, let a spider run alive!"

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  as good as the best in the world 世界级的
n. 运动员
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The athlete has a powerful physique.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an effort or attempt to do sth. 努力，尽力  v. try (to do sth.) 努力（做某事），尽力（做某事）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Please make every endeavor to arrive punctually.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. only likely to happen once in sb.'s life 一生中仅有一次的
n. an occupation, esp. regular paid work 职业，就业
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The automobile industry continues to be an important source of employment in that country.

NewWords.WordPhrase: make preparations beforehand 事先做好准备
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Before you go near a stockbroker, do your homework.

NewWords.WordPhrase: try hard to obtain 努力争取，追求
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Are you planning to go after Peter's job when he leaves?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （篮球） 投篮得分
a. not ready 未准备好的
a.  （体育） 反手的
ad.  by the way 顺便提起地，附带地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Incidentally, this wine goes particularly well with cheese.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. one of a pair or team in a sport or game; person who takes part in an activity with another or others 搭档；同伙
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is one of the five partners in the firm of lawyers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 咯咯地笑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The professor chuckled when we told her that we were afraid of her.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 类，档次；托架，撑架
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Women outnumbered men three to two in the over-65 age bracket.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. with regard to the body; according to the laws of nature 身体上地；按自然法则地   physical a. of or concerning the body; of or concerning the laws of nature 身体的；按自然法则的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Physically I find him very attractive, but we don't have the same outlook on life.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 构造，结构
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Morphology is concerned with the structure of words, syntax with the structure of phrases and sentences.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 肺
n. an attempt or try; a sharp snapping sound 尝试；噼啪声   take/have a crack (at) try to do (sth.) 尝试
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They have decided to have a crack at the doubles championship.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 肯尼亚人
n. a time limit by which sth. must be done 最终期限
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Tomorrow is the deadline for the students to hand in their term paper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. possible to be measured 可测量的
capable of being identified 可识别的，可确认的  identify vt. 识别，鉴别
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In her bright yellow coat, she was easily identifiable in the crowd.

NewWords.WordPhrase: change the situation or outlook; have an effect 改变现状或观点； 产生影响
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Having a good teacher has made all the difference for Alex.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. thoroughly, absolutely 完全，彻底
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was downright rude to me.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  extremely or unpleasantly dirty 非常肮脏的，污秽的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The beggar was in filthy rags.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  exhibit, display 展示，显示
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was heavily-built and sported a red moustache.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. impossible to penetrate 穿不透的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The mountain range was an almost impenetrable barrier between the two continents.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. impenetrable by bullets 防弹的
n.  分割物，隔离物
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Glass partitions divided the room into individual offices.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in a polite manner 有礼貌地   courteous a. polite and respectful, well-mannered 有礼貌的，举止得体的
移动电话，手机
vt. utter abruptly and thoughtlessly 未加思索地冲口说出
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As soon as the teacher put forward the question, he blurted the answer out.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. try to look into private facts about a person 窥探，探究
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We don't want people prying into our affairs.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a wise and trusted guide and advisor 良师益友，导师，顾问
about 大约
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has an annual salary in the neighborhood of $40,000.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in a generous manner 慷慨地，不吝啬地   generous a. giving or willing to give freely 大方的，慷慨的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The farmer generously allowed us to camp on his land.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 喷气式飞机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Commercial air transport has experienced massive growth with the advent of jet airliners.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. joyously 快乐地，欢欣地
more than anyone /one can ever imagine 无论如何也想不到的，做梦也不敢想的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Ten years ago it was beyond my wildest dreams that I could afford a car.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 闪烁，闪耀
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The diamond ring sparkled in the sunlight.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  立场, 观点   from one's/the standpoint (of) from one's/the viewpoint (of) 从…的观点来看
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. From humans standpoint, all of the world's physical resources are in finite supply.
